## Introduction

This is a basic overview of homotopy type theory (HoTT) formalized in `Agda`. It
is only one file and has been type-checked by `Agda 2.5.4`. No other libraries
are required to type-check this file. This library is full of synonyms for types
and constructors, their names intend to be the common names found in the
literature but also to be *mnemotechnic* names.

![path](/assets/png-images/mini-hott.jpeg){: width="220px" align="right" }

{: .only-website }

  **URL link**: [https://jonaprieto.github.io/mini-hott/](https://jonaprieto.github.io/mini-hott/).

To be consistent with homotopy type theory, we tell `Agda` to not use *Axiom K* for
type-checking by using the option `without-K`.

<pre class="Agda">{% raw %}<a id="1187" class="Symbol">{-#</a> <a id="1191" class="Keyword">OPTIONS</a> <a id="1199" class="Option">--without-K</a> <a id="1211" class="Symbol">#-}</a>{% endraw %}</pre>

This code is working in progress and it's only for learning purposes. We have
based it on other similar developments. Please check out the references at the
end of this article.

## Basic types

Without Axiom K, `Agda`'s `Set` is not a good name for universes in HoTT and we
rename `Set` to `Type`. Our type judgments then will include the universe level
as one explicit argument.

### Natural numbers

Natural numbers are the initial algebra for a constant and a
successor function. The `BUILTIN` declaration allows us to use
natural numbers in Arabic notation.

## Equality type

In HoTT, we have a different interpretation of type theory in which the
set-theoretical notion of *sets* for *types* is replaced by the topological
notion of *spaces*. A type judgment like `x : A` means that the point `x`â€Œâ€Œ is
*in* the topological space `A`â€Œâ€Œ. Furthermore, we include the *Identity type* as
a primary type. The inhabitants of these identity types will not be longer
interpreted as *proofs of equalities* but as *paths* in a Path space, an
Identity type.

### Homogeneous equality

The Identity type is defined as an inductive type. Its induction principle is
the J-eliminator.

#### J eliminator

The elimination principle for the identity type is the path induction. It allows
us to define an outgoing function from the identity type to a dependent type â€Œâ€Œ
as we see in the `J` definition below.

*Paulin-Mohring J rule*

## Equational reasoning

Equational reasoning is a way to write readable chains of equalities.

```agda

      b =âŸ¨ q âŸ©

      d =âŸ¨ s âŸ©
      e âˆ
```
{% endraw %}

Now, we can define a convenient syntax sugar for `ap` in
equational reasoning.

<pre class="Agda">{% raw %}<a id="11165" class="Keyword">infixl</a> <a id="11172" class="Number">40</a> <a id="11175" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#10924" class="Function">ap</a>
<a id="11178" class="Keyword">syntax</a> <a id="11185" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#10924" class="Function">ap</a> f p <a id="11192" class="Symbol">=</a> p |in-ctx f{% endraw %}</pre>

Let's suppose we have a lemma:
{% raw %}
```agda
  lemma : a == b
  lemma = _
```
{% endraw %}
used in an equational reasoning like:
{% raw %}
```agda
  t : a == e
  t = f a =âŸ¨ ap f lemma âŸ©
      f b
      âˆ
```
{% endraw %}

Then, we can now put the lemma in front:
{% raw %}
```agda
  t : a == e
  t = f a =âŸ¨ lemma |in-ctx f âŸ©
      f b
      âˆ
```
{% endraw %}

## Homotopy

> In a type-theoretical sense, a homotopy between two
> functions is a family of equalities between their applications.

The context:
<pre class="Agda">{% raw %}<a id="29922" class="Keyword">module</a> <a id="Homotopy"></a><a id="29929" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29929" class="Module">Homotopy</a> <a id="29938" class="Symbol">{</a><a id="29939" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29939" class="Bound">â„“áµ¢</a> <a id="29942" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29942" class="Bound">â„“â±¼</a><a id="29944" class="Symbol">}</a> <a id="29946" class="Symbol">{</a><a id="29947" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29947" class="Bound">A</a> <a id="29949" class="Symbol">:</a> <a id="29951" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#1839" class="Function">Type</a> <a id="29956" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29939" class="Bound">â„“áµ¢</a><a id="29958" class="Symbol">}</a> <a id="29960" class="Symbol">{</a><a id="29961" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29961" class="Bound">P</a> <a id="29963" class="Symbol">:</a> <a id="29965" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29947" class="Bound">A</a> <a id="29967" class="Symbol">â†’</a> <a id="29969" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#1839" class="Function">Type</a> <a id="29974" href="{% endraw %}{{ site.baseurl }}{% link _posts/2018-07-06-mini-hott.md %}{% raw %}#29942" class="Bound">â„“â±¼</a><a id="29976" class="Symbol">}</a> <a id="29978" class="Keyword">where</a>{% endraw %}</pre>

Let $$f , g : \prod\limits_{(x:A)} P(x)$$ be two sections of a
type family $$P : A \to \mathcal{U}$$. A **homotopy** from $$f$$ to $$g$$
is a dependent function of type

{: .equation }
  $$ (f \sim g) :\equiv \prod\limits_{x : A} (f(x) = g(x)). $$

{: .foldable until="5"}

## Decidable equality

A type has decidable equality if any two of its
elements are equal or different. This would be a particular
instance of the Law of Excluded Middle that holds even if we do not
assume Excluded Middle.

## Hlevels

### Propositions

Propositions as described on the main text. A type
is a proposition if we can create a function making any two of its
elements equal. We create a type of propositions.

### Sets

Sets are types without any higher dimensional structure, all
parallel paths are homotopic and the homotopy is given by a
continuous function on the two paths.

### Lemmas

Higher levels of the homotopical structure, where the
first levels are:

- Contractible types (0)
- Propositions (1)
- Sets (2)

They would correspond to homotopy levels. We only work with
these first levels.

### Half-adjoints

Half-adjoints are an auxiliary notion that helps us
to define a suitable notion of equivalence, meaning that it is a
proposition and that it captures the usual notion of equivalence.

### Quasiinverses

Two functions are quasi-inverses if we can construct a function providing
`(g âˆ˜ f) x = x` and `(f âˆ˜ g) y = y` for any given `x` and `y`.

## Set truncation

An analogous form of truncation for Sets instead of
Propositions. It truncates any higher-dimensional homothopical
structure.

## Higher inductive types

### Interval

between them (an element of the equality type). The path is nontrivial.

## Fundamental group

Definition of the fundamental group of a type.
Let a:A be one point of the type. The fundamental group on a is the
group given by proofs of the equality (a=a).
